content.description: A solar power engineer took a random sample of houses and installed the same type of solar panels using two different methods on each house to investigate whether there is a mean difference in the angles of installation between the two methods for all houses in the population of interest. The engineer found the sample mean difference between the two methods to be <math alttext="0.2" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.2</mn></math> degree and the <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mi>p</mi></math>-value for a two-sided matched-pairs <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>-test for the mean difference to be <math alttext="0.65" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.65</mn></math>.
content.question: Assuming the conditions for inference are met, which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the <math alttext="p" overflow="scroll"><mi>p</mi></math>-value?

choices.label: The probability that the null hypothesis is true is <math alttext="0.65" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.65</mn></math>.

If the null hypothesis is true, the probability is <math alttext="0.65" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.65</mn></math> of observing a mean difference of <math alttext="0.2" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.2</mn></math> degree or <math alttext="negative 0.2" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>0.2</mn></math> degree.

If the null hypothesis is true, the probability is <math alttext="0.65" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.65</mn></math> of observing a mean difference of greater than <math alttext="0.2" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.2</mn></math> degree or less than <math alttext="negative 0.2" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>0.2</mn></math> degree.

If the null hypothesis is true, the probability is <math alttext="0.65" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.65</mn></math> of observing a mean difference of greater than <math alttext="0.2" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.2</mn></math> degree.

If the null hypothesis is true, the probability is <math alttext="0.65" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.65</mn></math> of observing a mean difference of less than <math alttext="negative 0.2" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>0.2</mn></math> degree.

content.answer: If the null hypothesis is true, the probability is <math alttext="0.65" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.65</mn></math> of observing a mean difference of greater than <math alttext="0.2" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.2</mn></math> degree or less than <math alttext="negative 0.2" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>0.2</mn></math> degree.

topic.text: 7.5: Carrying Out a Test for a Population Mean

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
